item.name: Rex: Final Days of an Empire
item.comment:
[b]THE INFLUENCE MUST FLOW[/b]
Sneering Lazax Noble: "We were conquering star systems when the rest of you were still afraid of thunder."
Pig-stinky Hu-man: "Who's afraid of thunder now?"
[size=12]~•~[/size]
Best first player marker in all gamedom...
[imageid=2741515 small inline][imageid=2741516 small inline]
...[i]The Beermat of Preëminence![/i]
[b]Thoughts after first play:[/b]
Rex, AKA "Wrecks"
Really, very nifty. The wildly asymmetrical player powers make for interesting combinations during alliances, the whole thing being a variable machine the players can construct as they go—a machine that spends most of the time shuddering sideways while gloriously out of whack; much of the experience is spent desperately trying to get everything back in balance, only to have it veer madly into crazyland again. But that's what makes it memorable—it's rife with delicious quintuplethink and opportunities for clever play.
The shoehorned [i]Twilight Imperium[/i] IP, which is, according to FFG's marketing, "rich, vibrant, and evocatively adjectival", is okay, I guess, though it does end up making it feel more like David Lynch's 1984 adaptation of [i]Dune[/i]—a familiar thing bent in weird ways. It's definitely in the "milk the cat" category.
[imageid=2745432 original] [size=7]Fig. 1 — [i]The genius of Frank Herbert knows no bounds.[/i][/size]

item.name: Risk
item.comment:
Much like [i]Monopoly[/i] it's not a [i]bad[/i] game—just hideously antiquated. The simplicity of the rules set makes it primarily a social game, a game of pilsner, pals and potty mouth.
[b]EDITIONS OWNED:[/b]
[b]The 1970s one with the caltrops[/b] :star::star::halfstar::nostar::nostar: My very favorite xmas present when I was 10 or so; played many times all by myself. Lovingly maintained in a state of arrested decay. Rating is for the standard Global Domination game, though it can shoot to [i]superawesome[/i] with the right people. And beer.
[b]2003 Edition[/b] :star::star::star::nostar::nostar: Self-purchased for the mission cards. Makes the base game waaay more playable.
[b][gameid=1829][/b] :star::star::star::halfstar::nostar: Self-purchased for science fiction theme. Good stuff—almost an entirely different game.
[b][gameid=8107][/b] :star::star::star::halfstar::nostar: Self-purchased because I'm a fanboy. Pretty cool for what it is.
[b][gameid=15045][/b] :star::star::star::halfstar::nostar: Purchased for the kids. (Yeah, right.) Pretty decent 2-player game.
[b][gameid=22551][/b] :star::star::star::halfstar::nostar: Purchased for me. (The biggest kid in the house.) Great for 3-players.
[b][gameid=37198][/b] :star::star::star::star::nostar: Fantastic additions to the base engine—cities, capitals, objectives, a new card-exchange regime (turn in 2-10 stars for 2-30 troops) and a VP-based victory condition make this a completely different game.
UPDATE: I really, really like the idea of [i]Risk[/i]—the stupid-simple conflict game of smack-talk and dice-chucking—far more than actually playing it. It would be difficult to convince me to play the default Global Domination version of this, no matter how tempting the snacks, beer and company. I'm much better disposed toward the improved versions—missions, [i]2210[/i], [i]LotR[/i], or one of the Star Wars ones. Even better, the 2008 Revised Edition.
That said, I do play an awful lot of Global Domination [i]Risk[/i] in digital formats—you can tap out an entire game in less than 20 minutes.* Stupid fun.
And then there's always this:
[b][thread=694761][/thread][/b]
[size=7]*Says an embarrassing amount about how much time gets eaten up with all the dice rolling and comparing...[/size]

item.name: Risk 2210 A.D.
item.comment: This version makes the original look like the drooling invalid it is.

item.name: Risk Legacy
item.comment:
[COLOR=#CC0000][b]OH SWEET JESUS HOW DO YOU SLEEVE A STICKER[/b][/COLOR]
UPDATE: It's a game! It's an art project! It's a cruel psychological experiment! It's all these things and more... like a roller coaster full of plus-size swimsuit models* it thrills and titillates through the ups and downs. Only three games in and the burning of Earth 12769 already has a unique narrative. [i]And this is without opening any packets.[/i] With sticker and Sharpie we have left our mark on this embattled world—the warlords of Thunderia, New Sparta and Sasquatchistan showing themselves to be more than willing to pop nukes in pristine old-growth forests and water the virgin plains with the blood of orphans in order to... to... uh, I used to know the reasons why, but now all I know is [i]hate.[/i]
Don't fool yourself—if you're not defacing the hell out of this game you're not even getting 1% of the experience it has to offer. It's like the difference between masturbating to an underwear catalog vs. a threesome with real people. Tell yourself whatever makes you feel better all alone with your anal retentive proclivities, but if you're not putting your mark on it [i]you are not playing the game.[/i]
This is, only three games in, among the best gaming experiences I've ever had.
[size=7]*Or a gaggle of hairless, pouty, male underwear models flopped on a tatty sofa if that's your thing instead.[/size]

item.name: Risk: Star Wars Edition
item.comment:
Deeper than it appears on the surface, this mass-market dice-chucker is actually a hoot-and-a-half with just the littlest bit of gamegeek gloss.
Also, make damn sure you stop by here:
[b][thread=1447610][/thread][/b]
(Black Series)

item.name: Risk: Star Wars Original Trilogy Edition
Risk: Star Wars – The Clone Wars Edition
item.comment:
It's [i]Risk[/i], and if you're a hater, then get ready to turn your nose up and move along—there's nothing for you here.
If you don't mind the [i]Risk[/i] base engine, then this one has a couple of neat little quirks for you. First and foremost, the triple use of cards leads to some acutely agonizing decisions. They can be turned in as sets to gain reinforcements, OR used to build a ship, OR played for their special effect text. Secondly, the non-compatability of the two armies within each faction makes for more interesting play. The Republic and the Separatists each have two armies, and no matter how many players there are, all four armies will be in play. The two armies within each faction cooperate for the end-goal, but they cannot share territory or cards—and each army gets its own turn.
The Order 66 shenannigans add a nerve-wracking thematic clock to the game; watching systems flip to the dark side is a nail-biter for the Republic player... culminating in a desperate, last-gasp mad-dash assault on Palpatine. The all-or-nothing feel of the endgame is simply delicious.
There's not as much going on here as there is in [i]2210[/i] or [i]LotR[/i], but my 11-year-old son and I had a great time. Overall a good rootbeer & pretzels game, provided you like the modern Star Wars and don't mind [i]Risk[/i]. Lucky for me, I find I'm hovering at a sweet-spot of equanimity in respect to both.

item.name: Risk: The Lord of the Rings
item.comment: Takes the best things about [i]Risk[/i] and freshens 'em up with hefty dose of [i]LotR[/i] (and a time limit).

item.name: Risk: The Lord of the Rings Trilogy Edition
item.comment: (Comments in my [thread=15454]User Review[/thread].)

item.name: RoboRally
item.comment: A great wad of chaos for those who like their games silly and raucous. It helps a bunch to have a solid visual/spatial imagination, but even then things often go horribly wrong. A real hoot if you're into real hoots. And I am.

item.name: Roll for the Galaxy
item.comment:
[center][size=6][COLOR=#878787]LIFETIME GAME [microbadge=28495]:star:[microbadge=28496] "PLAY FOREVER"[/COLOR][/size][/center]
Aspiring interstellar overlords commit handpicked citizens to a mind-warping battle school where they are... [i]changed[/i]. These agents are then dispatched on desperate missions across the cosmos—leading a surgical strike force of war-painted starships, or skin crawling with invisible tattoos that reconfigure into malware under certain wavelengths of light, or their skulls the vessels for a single dangerous idea.
Tomorrow, tomorrow belongs to the Ascendant—and there is no better way to leap for the brass ring than with a boot in your grasping rival's face.
[microbadge=26108]
[i]An unalloyed slam-dunk.[/i] As a rabid [i]Race[/i] fan I am obviously predisposed to love this, but honestly, [i]Roll[/i] has far exceeded even my naturally high expectations. Added to everything that's already fantastic about the Mother Game we have a gorgeous feast for the senses—the spray of color, the sound of the dice in the cups, the shaking and slamming, the digging around in that black bag for deliciously textured tiles.
It's a sci-fi jacuzzi with built-in mind-massage attachment.*
UPDATE: 11 games in and the response from newbs is overwhelming—all of them have found this far more accessible than [i]Race[/i] proper. I believe it has to do with the fact that any given [i]Race[/i] game is completely hidden inside an opaque deck of cards, meaning that the game doesn't open up until you're familiar with the contents of that deck, and this requires either a bunch of boring study or many—[i]so many[/i]—crushing defeats. With [i]Roll[/i], on the other hand, the dice give you a pretty big hint as to what's possible on your turn and so tend to drive play in more obvious directions right out of the gate.
Besides, fiddling around with the dice to "program" your turn feels like you're [i]actually doing something[/i] rather than just looking at a bunch of cards and having no real idea of what to do next.
Includes: [thing=175754]Ambition[/thing]
[size=7]*Pants optional (but not recommended).
[b]A Very Important Note on Space Marine Recruitment:[/b] As the recruitment protocols are a preëxisting component of the drinking water on most civilized worlds, the consumption of them constitutes retroactive consent. This is only important for the recruit's relatives as the recruits themselves are neurologically predisposed to be "just fine" with the sudden change in life-trajectory. [i]Oorah![/i][/size]

item.name: Roll Through the Ages: The Bronze Age
item.comment: A not-bad filler made even better when someone invented religion, declared themselves "Monkey-Pope" and began to spread the Good Word of how the Monkey God wanted to "hump our faces".

item.name: Rook
item.comment:
Trick-taking without the Devil worship!
Low speed, high drag. This game is a lot better on the planet where they never invented [gameid=215]. I understand that Rook glows warmly with nostalgia for some folks; unfortunately I came to this way too late in the game for it to matter.
PURGED

item.name: Rory's Story Cubes
item.comment: From now on every RPG I play will use these for all action resolution.

item.name: Rummikub
item.comment: Better have those cerebral afterburners installed...

item.name: Runebound (First Edition)
item.comment:
Feels like all the best parts of a complete role-playing campaign in a single evening, where half the fun is telling the stories of the combats and circumstances surrounding the encounters.
Be warned, though—downtime is a SERIOUS problem—I would NEVER want to play this with more than three.
My son and I are enjoying the hell out of this one—a great way to spend a lazy Saturday afternoon. Rootbeer & pretzels, anyone?
Included: [gameid=12108]
(Gave this to Joe & kids.)

item.name: Runebound (Second Edition)
item.comment:
[center][size=6][COLOR=#878787]LIFETIME GAME [microbadge=28495]:star:[microbadge=28496] "PLAY FOREVER"[/COLOR][/size][/center]
NOTE: Rating is for the [i]Runebound[/i] system as a whole—the base game, with nothing but the "Rise of the Dragonlords" adventure, pulls a solid 8. It soars to a 10 when considered with the plethora of expansions, especially the Adventure Variants (each with a different overarching plot).
A fun adventure game system from the "pull a card, read the encounter, roll some dice" family. Can be boring with dull people—it requires a certain amount of storytelling ability to make it interesting. Why do you get a plus to Diplomacy after you kill the Hill Troll? Because you made a backpack out of his scrotum, that's why. Plays best with 2 or, maaaybe, 3.
UPDATE: We managed nine plays out of the 1st Edition, and that was with no expansions. As this is a "Saturday afternoon" game (taking several hours) that means we got somewhere around two months' worth of Saturdays out of it. Two months of solid play off a single scenario. With all the scenarios FFG has been pumping out since 2nd Edition debuted, the replay value of this one blows through the roof, soars into orbit and then takes a hard left into a magical wormhole... who can say where it will end. Huge amount of bang-for-buck on this one.
UP-UPDATE: Tweaks that make for more gaming goodness, IMO:
1) Use the "shorter game" rules (essentially making it cheaper to level up).
2) Separate the massive market deck into three piles: the Tavern (allies), the Smithy (weapons & armor), and the Bazaar (a catch-all for familiars, magic items & artifacts). This allows players to really target the holes in their kit/entourage without endless turns of market-stepping loads of junk they don't need.
3) Ignore PvP. (This is a personal "play-style" choice as there's nothing wrong with it; we just found it slowed things down.)
While these tweaks speed up the game, I'm not saying the game needs speeding up. For a lazy Saturday afternoon (especially a bad weather one) this game expands to fill the time nicely. We've found that the above tweaks will take an afternoon game and turn it into a evening game. And that just means we get to play more!
UP-UP-UPDATE: [b]10 June 2015[/b]—Completed my set with an unopened, unpunched, sun-bleached [i]Mists of Zanaga[/i] that had been kicking around an FLGS for God knows how long... (Well, for at least five years, right?)

item.name: Runebound (Third Edition)
item.comment:
[b]tl;dr[/b] — A solid storytelling/adventure game that's best with two players; the token-casting combat system is better than dice.
[COLOR=#CC0000][i]There's something deeply satisfying about taking a whip and an axe to a necromancer.[/i][/COLOR]
Say, friend—are you looking for a game with
- expendable sidekicks - wizard-scalping - the "Festival of Scabs" - and a French-kissing ettin?
Well, this is it! I found these things in the box—[i]and more![/i]—and so can you!*
[size=7]*DISCLAIMER: Specific instances of absurd fantasy tropes may or may not actually be in box and may instead reside in very specific skulls, one of which may or may not be yours. Horrible Black Void where prohibited.[/size]
[size=14][b]•[/b][/size]
[b]After 10 plays:[/b] [COLOR=#979797](5x 2p, 3x 3p, 2x 4p)[/COLOR]
[i]Comparison with 2nd Edition.[/i] I am a HUGE [i]Runebound[/i] fan—having burned through 1st Edition and collected a complete set of 2nd—and I really like what 3rd is up to. It's an entirely different game, and doesn't supersede or obsolete 2nd in any way. I will continue to play both, for different reasons: 2nd to bask in a fully-realized fantasy adventure world, 3rd to explore the new thing. Comparisons between the two at this point are useless—remember how thin and spare 2nd was when it first came out? 3rd is just a new beginning...
[i]Emergent narrative.[/i] When it comes to games in general I'm most interested in the stories they tell; when it comes to adventure games it's [i]all[/i] I care about. I don't give a fig for the systems, mechanics, or underlying math—[i]I just want a good story.[/i] My only questions are "Was it fun?" and "Was it memorable?" 3rd nails both, and so far [url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/plays/thing/181530?userid=9685]the stories have been fantastic[/url].
[i]Build the character you want.[/i] Everyone I've played this with really enjoys the fact that you can build pretty much any kind of character you want to play. Though each character starts on a path you are not forced down it—you can change it up based on how skills and gear come out. Lord Hawthorne can become a powerful mage even as Master Thorn deviates into a combat monster, leaping from wall to wall lopping off heads... It's cool to hunt for killer combos of abilities/skills/gear—there's a lot of very powerful synergy hidden in the game.
[i]Play time.[/i] Count on at least one hour per player; you can knock 30 minutes off the total if everyone's experienced. This means 2p in 90 minutes (!) but you're still looking down the barrel of 3½ hours for 4p.
[i]Player count.[/i] This is, first and foremost, a story game—and as such it suffers at max player count where there's just too much story to pay attention to. With 2p you have your story and your opponent's story (as well as being engaged in every round of combat, either doing it or running the monster); delightful. With 3p you have two other stories to pay attention to; a stretch, but not unreasonable. With 4p you have [i]three other[/i] stories and I find it's just too much story flying around as all the action becomes a mishmash of narrative elements to no good effect. The sweet spot is definitely 2-3p.
[i]Final analysis.[/i] While I could go into more detail about what I've come to love about this, I won't, for the simple reason that it's a game of exploration and adventure—and that means it's best experienced in person over time rather than laid out for you here. You're going to have to figure out for yourself how to become a hero in this world—how best to prepare for that final fight as the clock ticks down; how to interleave movement toward your next goal with mundane pick-up-and-deliver jobs and exploration quests; how best to utilize and sequence your interactions with the three kinds of encounter decks... and so on. You could sit down, read all the cards, and min-max your way into an empty, soulless win bereft of surprise or novelty—or you could [i]just play[/i], explore the world organically and become that hero through trial and error across many raucous sessions with friends. The resulting stories are the real treasure here.
[size=14][b]•[/b][/size]

item.name: Runebound: Artifacts and Allies
item.comment: A nice thick wad of variety, and best of all—it's cheap!

item.name: Runebound: Beasts and Bandits
item.comment: More challenge cards (greens, yellows, blues and a red) just mean more meaty [i]Runebound[/i] goodness. Hardly necessary, but more means no two games will ever be the same!

item.name: Runebound: Cult of the Rune
item.comment: This is the expansion that truly fulfills the promise of the [i]Runebound[/i] system, showing just what can be done by swapping out a few cards while adding a few small components and a single breath's worth of new rules. The result is an entirely new adventure that feels nothing like the base game. A must-have for all [i]Runebound[/i] owners.

item.name: Runebound: Drakes and Dragonspawn
item.comment: Threw this into the mix, don't even really notice it. But then, that's the hallmark of a good expansion, right?

item.name: Runebound: Relics of Legend
item.comment:
The banners are about as useful as cartoon-character bedsheets on a stick. Everyone groans when they come out—especially the poor sap who wasted their Market Step pulling it. Otherwise a great expansion.
UPDATE: Removed banners to reduce poor sappage.

item.name: Runebound: Rituals and Runes
item.comment:
The new ritual mechanic is nifty.
SIDE NOTE: [i]Runebound[/i] is one of the few "system" games that I don't feel bad buying every last expansion for. Most system games hit a point where more stops being better ([i]Carcassonne[/i], anyone?). With [i]Runebound[/i], the excellent minds at Fantasy Flight have found a way to make "more" mean "nuance". Kudos & pass the dice!

item.name: Runebound: Sands of Al-Kalim
item.comment:
Very different feel from the base game. It's an often awful choice whether to travel by day or night... do you bake in the desert sun, stumbling along with withered lips and wild eyes or do you chance getting ambushed in the pale light of the desert moon? Also, the travels and travails of the legendary quests are a great change of pace from the "kill reds until you get the game-winning one" strategy of The Rise of the Dragon Lords. You only have to kill a single red (any one will do) to set yourself up for the endgame, but even that doesn't seal the win—you still need to complete that fourth quest. All in all, great fun.
Recommended.
PS. A nifty detail: the more legendary quests you complete, the more narrow your possible story becomes; some legendary allies will leave you if you kill certain encounters, for example. Sometimes you have to flee a monster in order not to upset the very entourage that makes you a legend... The result is that power comes at a price—the more you can do, the more judicious you have to be. So instead of just juggernauting across the landscape and leaving a trail of dead, you actually have to pick your fights based on the legend you are building. This helps keep the stories thematic and prevents (to some extent) run away leaders.

item.name: Runebound: Shadows of Margath (First Edition)
item.comment:
A subtle (30 card) sprinkle of spice. Definitely upped the fun factor.
(Gave this to Joe & kids.)

item.name: Runebound: Shadows of Margath (Second Edition)
item.comment: Hardly necessary, but good stuff nonetheless. It doesn't create a noticeable impact on the game so much, but, like a hint of spice, it's in there, altering the experience in its own small way.

item.name: Runebound: The Dark Forest
item.comment: Adds a bunch of evil faeries, like everyone is gorked out of their minds on absinthe or something. Still, good stuff.

item.name: Runebound: The Scepter of Kyros
item.comment: A terrific expansion. The new story works well and it's just plain fun being a giantkiller. The non-apocalyptic endgame plays out much better than the original Rise of the Dragon Lords scenario. A must-have for all [i]Runebound[/i] owners.

item.name: Runebound: The Seven Scions
item.comment: Looks fantastic—and it plays co-op!

item.name: Runebound: The Terrors of the Tomb
item.comment: Adds a necrotic dollop of undead flavor to the mix. Mmm-mmm good!

item.name: Runebound: Traps and Terrors
item.comment: The traps bring a new flavor to the mix—very fun.

item.name: Runebound: Walkers of the Wild
item.comment: [i]Runebound[/i] is like pizza & sex: Even when it's bad, it's still pretty good.

item.name: Runebound: Weapons of Legend
item.comment: The new "equipping allies" mechanic is cool and some of the new weapons are, like, [i]whoa.[/i] The Soul Eater is the nuclear weapon of [i]Runebound[/i]. If ever there was a reason for PvP, it's to take it away from anyone who's not you.

item.name: Runewars
item.comment:
A welcome respite from endless farming in the Brown Zone.
"Sack up 'n take yer beatin' like a man."
UPDATE: Rating of 8 based on box contents & rules. Actual play pending... but highly anticipated.
UP-UPDATE: First play had the Elves exterminating the Humans to the last child and then erasing them from the Chronicles of All Times & Peoples. THIS IS AN INCREDIBLE GAME. Makes [i]Twilight Imperium[/i] look like a steam-powered jitney next to a Lamborghini... with a supermodel who's been eating cupcakes [i]for the last six weeks[/i] draped most buxomly over the hood.*
[i]Agricola[/i], in its dreams, [i]wishes[/i] it was this nasty.
PS. The heroes are just fine as is. They act as:
[i]Spies![/i] (they allow you to look at Dragon Runes so you know where the real ones are)
[i]Saboteurs![/i] (they can pop off spells in the midst of the enemy just before you attack)
[i]Assassins![/i] (they kill & loot other heroes)
[i]Agents For The Win![/i] (they can get you more Dragon Runes).
They don't need to lead armies if you're using them to best advantage doing all of the above. Besides, hero ≠ general... do you really want some homeless wizard who smells like cat pee leading an army it took you two years to amass?
[size=7]*Or doing 'roids while hitting the weight pile and the tanning booth if that's more your speed.[/size]

item.name: S.F.3.D. Original
item.comment: Standard hex-counter wargame fare. Not bad—just uninspired.

item.name: Saboteur
item.comment: Played a couple recent games of this with 10 (!) players, everyone from a 12-year-old niece to a 70+ grandma. Worked suprisingly well, like, [i]eerily[/i] well. Most were non-gamers, several were merely casual. Gramma marveled at how much fun could be had with just a deck of cards, and how much [gameid=1269] sucked in comparison. She was also pretty good at being the Grammateur.

item.name: Samurai
item.comment: Sweet screamin' Kali on a dirt bike! Tactics scythe in and out of shadows; the smallest move opens gaping wounds of possibilities. For such an abstract game, it sure feels like war.

item.name: San Juan
item.comment:
Take [i]Puerto Rico[/i] and boil off all the fussy crap. What's left in the bottom of the cauldron is a gooey tar of condensed fun. Roll the tar out and cut it into rectangles and you have [i]San Juan[/i].
This one wins out over its older brother in three very important areas—it's accessible, portable and short. In the time it would take you to play a single game of [i]Puerto Rico[/i] (not counting rules explanation (shudder)) you could play three games of this [i]including[/i] an overview of the rules. [i]San Juan[/i] has the potential to see far more table time than [i]PR[/i]. That make it clearly superior in my book. Recommended.
Component shot after a vigorous "gravity sorting":
[imageid=2643926 small]

item.name: Savage Worlds: Explorer's Edition
item.comment:
I get the feeling this is better suited as a tabletop minis game. As an RPG...
[q]Great idea, awful execution. The text routinely references rules that are nowhere to be found, and there's no index so you're often SOL figuring things out.
It wasn't until a thorough reading of the [rpgitem=47891][/rpgitem] book and cross-referencing that with the [rpgitem=44199][/rpgitem] book that I pieced together how combat and wounding work.
Lastly, having dice pools made up of different dice is gamey and takes away from fast, furious storytelling.
Ultimately disappointing—I love the format and where the creators are coming from, it just doesn't work for my group.[/q]

item.name: Scarab Lords
item.comment:
All the pleasure of a CCG without any of the abject agony. Branded with the usual Knizia hallmarks: complexity arising from simple rules, intuitive gameplay that leads to counter-intuitive strategies. All this and easy to learn, fast to play.
(Gave this to Dave.)

item.name: Schildi Schildkröte
item.comment: A fun little dexterity game—the turtle rolling mechanism is clever and leads to hilarious butts-up find-the-ball-under-the-bookcase moments.

item.name: Der schwarze Pirat
item.comment: Yet another mechanically interesting kid-Euro. I think the Europeans love their children more than we do, or, at least, are less cynical about the potential of their intellect.

item.name: Search for the Emperor's Treasure
item.comment: I loved this game so much in junior high that I borrowed my friend's copy (from Dragon Magazine), photocopied the parts, mounted them on cardboard and hand-colored them. This is the set I have to this day...

item.name: Seasons
item.comment:
Drop-dead gorgeous production values slathered over a so-so apparatus. After two plays I'm into it and looking forward to more, but will henceforth heed the common warning that 4p is just too much. Downtime was brutal and who knows, maybe it picks up with familiarity but I'm not interested in finding out.
It feels like an 8 but I'm gonna make [i]Seasons[/i] work for it.
Also: Big chunky dice FTW!
UPDATE: So, four plays in & I'm pretty sure this is just a 2p experience. Even with only 3p the downtime during two consecutive super-turns (with card play and effects chaining on and on and on...) is an enthusiasm killer. Especially when my stupid turn is "I gain two energy. Next!" followed by two more super-turns. [i]Gaaah.[/i]
UP-UPDATE: Six games in, it's an 8. Play time's picking up as we become more familiar with the cards and we haven't even cracked the "advanced" set of 20. Just plain friendly and appealing. What can I say? It's... [i]nice[/i]... like a warm, French bubble bath. I can soak.
UP-UP-UPDATE: [i]I slipped on the Temporal Boots, thinking I was all kinds of clever—only to find myself sprinting backwards, screaming, into the Port-A-Potty to suck yesterday's dump up through the hole.[/i]
[microbadge=24521]
Expansions:
[thing=136233]Enchanted Kingdom[/thing] [thing=148166]Path of Destiny[/thing]

item.name: Sequence for Kids
item.comment:
Good at what it does—teaching turn-taking, pattern recognition, matching, & good gamesmanship. It's not [i]Puerto Rico[/i] with sub-games of [i]Traders of Genoa[/i] everytime someone sells some coffee, but the four-year-old I get to play this with is genuinely happy for the winner—whoever that may be. I can't say the same for some adults... (Myself included. D'oh!)
Rating reflects play with a bright, shiny kid.

item.name: The Settlers of Catan
item.comment:
[i]With my Largest Army I will bring The One True Religion to your wretched and benighted peoples.[/i]
[microbadge=966]
A DESPERATE RACE AGAINST GENOCIDE
Four flavors of a mad religious cult—persecuted in the Mother Country—make landfall on an eerily uninhabited island* and immediately get cracking on converting the primordial landscape into armed camps and the machinery of war. An uneasy détente ensues as no one has the upper hand... but soon, soon one faction will reach the tipping point and become powerful enough to strike against the heretics [i]and wipe them out[/i].
FOR GOD COMMANDS IT
[size=7]*The whole "robber" thing is really just a false-flag op to sow chaos.[/size]
[microbadge=20990]
([gameid=27710] in the box.)

item.name: The Settlers of Catan Card Game
item.comment: Wanna play [i]Settlers[/i] without having someone chuck the robber at your head? This is it.

item.name: The Settlers of Catan: 5-6 Player Expansion
item.comment:
My first act as Lord of Catan is to declare Prima Nocta—ON ALL OF YOU.
All joking aside, this really wants to be a four-player ONLY game. It just doesn't work with the extra folks.
UPDATE: PURGED

item.name: The Settlers of Catan: Travel Edition
item.comment:
!!!
(In the camping bin.)

item.name: The Settlers of the Stone Age
item.comment:
This one has the best double entendre out of all the [i]Settlers[/i] games—yes, even better than the wood for sheep one.
Hint: How do you make an explorer?

item.name: Shadow Hunters
item.comment:
FINALLY—a short, fun, thematically interesting game for large groups. Whenever we hit 6, 7 or 8, no one wants to break up into two games for fear of being stuck at the "unfun" table. This usually means we get stuck playing the suck. What, exactly? I dunno, but whatever it was, it wasn't memorable.
Many have been calling this a better [gameid=3955], and indeed, it is.
Recommended.
UPDATE: Whoever let Hello Kitty do the translation on this one should be fired. Or is that "up-flamed into transemployment"?
[i]Hermit[/i] --> [i]Fortune-teller[/i]
[i]Erstwhile Altar[/i] --> [i]Ancient Altar[/i]
&c.

item.name: Shadows over Camelot
item.comment:
Fun-enough party game. Lots and lots of jogging on a converyor belt in front of a gnashing robot maw. Don't trip on your cloak!
Includes:
[boardgameaccessory=20229][/boardgameaccessory]

item.name: Shave a Sheep
item.comment: No matter how many times you snatch the wolf and jab it in their faces while screaming "BARK BARK BARK!!!" the kids jump and cry every time.

item.name: Slamwich
item.comment: I want to win in the worst way... and yet, I can't bring myself to man-slam those delicate kid hands when they're in the pile.

item.name: Sleuth
item.comment: A true deduction game, in the same vein as Einstein's "who owns the fish" puzzle. I enjoy it a great deal—but be aware that not everyone will. For some it feels like the Awful Tedious Bookkeeping Non-Adventure Game. YMMV.

item.name: Small World
item.comment:
A nifty little tactics puzzle. Played quickly with the full compliment of five. Everyone agreed that I won because I was allowed to go about my business unmolested.
[b][COLOR=#FF0000]NOTE: THIS GAME REQUIRES MOLESTATION[/color][/b]
Looking forward to playing it again. I doubt my rating will rise, though it could fall once the shine comes off...
UPDATE: This is a great game. Very simple rules means that it's worked as (gasp!) a [i]gateway[/i] game for absolute n00bz. Also, the tactical and strategic depths are both deceptively shallow—meaning that the obvious simplicity of the "pick up/put down/score" gameplay hides deeper decisions... When to bunch up into a hard knot and when to spread thin? When to decline? Who do you pick on, and how? The timing of these issues is what decides the winner.
Also, there is no shortage of absolute dick-moves in this game—I recommend mouthguards and running shoes, or someone's gonna lose teeth.
UP-UPDATE: 11 plays in (+1.4 bajillion plays on the iPad app) show this thing has functionally infinite replayability. [i]Love it![/i]
[microbadge=9109]
Expansions:
[thing=165458]A Spider's Web[/thing] [thing=144171]Royal Bonus[/thing]
[thing=84183]Necromancer Island[/thing]
[thing=71818]Tales & Legends[/thing]

item.name: Smart Ass
item.comment: I liked the graduated questions designed to trip up the impatient know-it-alls and favor the patient, but the die roll to see how far you advance on the board is asinine. Our team won, but the other team that had at least as many correct answers as we did never made it further than a quarter around the board due to shitty rolls and constantly landing on the "go back 3 spaces" space.

item.name: Smash Up
item.comment:
After 3 plays:
A lighter [i]take that[/i] card game with THE AWESOMEST THEME POSSIBLE: disparate genre tropes wedded as conjoined twins to do battle with enemy Frankendecks. The presentation and form promise hilarious, rapid back-and-forth; this is unrealized in actual play as everything bogs down with the reading Reading READING of too much text on most every card, leading to more rereading and rules-interaction head scratching.
Perhaps this will pick up with familiarity?
[microbadge=25235]

item.name: Snapshot
item.comment:
As an add-on for [i]Traveller[/i], this is rockin' like Dokken. Probably doesn't hold up if you're not a [i]Traveller[/i] fanatic or '80s hair-band fan...
[imageid=1545018 small] [size=7]Fig. 1 — [i]Dice don't lie; you been smoked, son.[/i][/size]

item.name: Snit's Revenge
item.comment: I played this EVERY DAY of seventh grade with the same guy. He never won. I am a [i]Snit's Revenge[/i] GENIUS.

item.name: Sorry!
item.comment:
Show them kids the meaning of the term [c]PWNAGE[/c] (& only ever with the three-card hand).
Whenever you "sorry" someone's pawn, be sure to slam your pawn down on the edge of theirs to turbo-fire it across the room. While eye-protection is optional, sarcastically screaming "SORRY!!!" is not.
PURGED

item.name: Sorry! Sliders
item.comment:
"Luke, you’ve switched off your targeting computer. What’s wrong?"
Picked this up based on raves from [b]Geeks I Trust™[/b] and busted it out first thing Saturday morning... played so many games with my youngest son I lost count. Our ruckus woke my lazy teen who then joined in for, yes, so many games I lost count.
[i]Sorry! Sliders[/i] has all the elements of the best dexterity games:
- It's rules light
- Instantly grokkable
- Uses skills or abilities everyone already posseses
- Observers think they have a shot at doing better than the person they just watched go.
I'm tempted to slap a 10 on this, and I expect it to end up there after a debut at a family function. We'll see what my regular game group thinks about this—they're old and crotchety, after all, with none of the childish glee that comes from flick-slamming another player's pawn into the netherrealm... okay, scratch that.
UPDATE: Okay, busted this out with my regular group of emotionally-stunted man-children who took one look at the box and made faces and directly questioned my manhood, mental state and geek cred... fast forward through More Games Than I Can Count™ and they were grappling with a new addiction, stunned and shamed that they just... couldn't... walk away.
Money Quote: "We should play this for money—five bucks a game."
Then, doing the This-Is-Not-Happening body-rock: "Just five more dollars... five more dollars..."
UP-UPDATE: It's a ten! I'll always be willing to play this, and really, who wouldn't at five minutes a game? The kicker for me was an extended session with my usual game group where we had five of us and hot-swapped the winner's seat. It's so good, and short, that the odd man out never got bored. In fact, the incentive to win became more than mere crowing-rights—it meant you could get a snack... and use the bathroom.

item.name: Space Alert
item.comment:
So much more than a mere game—this is an amazing artifact, a tool, in the exercise of teamwork, planning, and unforeseen consequences. Seriously—it could be used for real-life team training.
But before you wave off because you're worried you'll be forced to play this with your boss at a corporate retreat, know that it's tense, trying (in the good way) and most of all fun. The theme is hard-SF enough to feel serious, with just a dusting of levity that never becomes cartoony (something that turns me off of [i]Galaxy Trucker[/i]).
I was worried the audio track would be goofy and kitschy, but instead I found it to be brilliantly immersive.

item.name: Space Fighters
item.comment:
Gets a 4 for raw, unfiltered chutzpah.
[imageid=266785 small]

item.name: Space Hulk (second edition)
item.comment:
Probably the best Games Workshop game ever made. Tense and sublime.
(Gave this to Trevor.)

item.name: Space Hulk (third edition)
item.comment:
"Incoming blips... watch those corners..."
[i]Space Hulk[/i] is the best game that Games Workshop ever made, and this is the best edition of that game. Worth every penny.
For the Ameritrash-curious, this is as good as it gets—[i]Space Hulk[/i] shows just how transcendent games can be. It's the perfect example of why I bother to play games in the first place.
Easiest 10 I've ever given.

item.name: Space Hulk: Death Angel – The Card Game
item.comment:
An absolutely terrific distillation of the [i]Space Hulk[/i] experience as a card game. A real nail-biter, tense and filled with hard choices and awful [i]almost[/i] moments. (As any good co-op should be.)
There is a real sense of increasing claustrophobia as Space Marines are slain and the formation collapses in on itself; the way swarms of Genestealers shift and wheel to flank the cumbersome Terminators induces a delicious sense of being overwhelmed.
It is a game of grand cinematic moments—[i]after luring a great mass of the swarm into the proximity of an aeons-corroded Promethium tankage, Brother Noctis sacrificed himself to obliterate the foul xenos in a cleansing firestorm[/i]—as well as careful strategizing with teammates to interleave actions into a tightly choreographed dance of death. When you pull it off, it's exhilarating. (Most of the time you won't.)
[i]Love it.[/i]
UPDATE: [i]Okay, anything other than a zero and I'm good—[/i]
[BGCOLOR=#FF0000][COLOR=#FFFFFF][c] [/c][b]0[/b][c] [/c][/COLOR][/BGCOLOR]
[i]Two to teleport, just don't roll a—[/i]
[size=13][BGCOLOR=#FF0000][COLOR=#FFFFFF][c] [/c][b]0[/b][c] [/c][/COLOR][/BGCOLOR][/size]
[i]NOW YOU WILL KNOW THE EMPEROR'S WRATH AS I UNLEASH DREAD POWER IN A CORUSCATING CHAIN OF AGONY THROUGH YOUR HELLISH COHORT—[/i]
[size=21][BGCOLOR=#FF0000][COLOR=#FFFFFF][c] [/c][b]0[/b][c] [/c][/COLOR][/BGCOLOR][/size]
It is the number of confirmed kills, the blinking ammo display, sarge's lifesigns indicator. It is the sum total of all your efforts:

item.name: Spinergy
item.comment: Write & sing a toothpaste jingle containing the following words: asteroid, ice, suspicion. (And try not to spit-take your drink.) WARNING: Ultra-high activation energy required to play.

item.name: Splendor
item.comment:
Players are Renaissance merchants vying to obtain gem mines, transportation networks, and swanky shops as fronts for human trafficking.*
[size=7]*Those goddamn nobles and their foul appetites are just horrible. [i]Horrible.[/i][/size]

item.name: Split-Level Aggravation
item.comment: The basic game gets a well-deserved two, with plus-two points for looking like a prop from [i]Space: 1999[/i].

item.name: The Spoils
item.comment:
From the designers: "A dystopian absurdist fantasy." Fnord!
UPDATE: I really don't want to like this game... but it's not letting me not like it.
UP-UPDATE: At this point [i]The Spoils[/i] is a game that's good enough. The theme is an easy 10. The art is another effortless 10. But the play... [shrug] As I said, good enough, a solid 7, nothing wrong here, no tumors under the petticoats, but nothing that hauls me back for more, either. I'll play if asked, no problem—and if I never offer to play it's only because it's just slipped my mind.

item.name: Stack Market
item.comment: A fun-enough party game. I love pulling some Enron/WorldCom-style accounting practices (stacking five dice in a super-crappy "Leaning Tower of Pesos"), taking your 10k payout and then riding the ejection seat on a burning plume of investors' dreams into your next company.

item.name: Star Munchkin
item.comment:
Not quite as much fun as fantasy [i]Munchkin[/i]. Perhaps my nerd credentials need to be checked.
UPDATE: [i]Munchkin[/i], as a knobbed-up commentary on fantasy RPGs, really only works when it's holding up its funhouse mirror to the fantasy genre. I've never played a science fiction RPG the way I played [i]Dungeons & Dragons[/i] in 8th grade... so this doesn't work for me at all.
I would much rather just play fantasy [i]Munchkin[/i].

item.name: Star Realms
item.comment:
Good God but the box is some kind of joke—it actually tore as I opened it, and this was going in forewarned of its flimsiness! I suppose the designers, as [gameid=463] fiends, consider deck packaging to be the equivalent of sausage casings, only there to keep the meaty bits in one place until wolfed down. I recommend immediate replacement with, say, a translucent deck box.
First couple plays: Just like the last breath torn from your lungs during a decompression event, this is short and far sweeter than you'd think. I am especially impressed with what must have been a great deal of editing on the part of the designers in order to arrive at such simplicity when it would have been so easy—and surely seductive—to just keep piling on more and more...
And it turns out I'm a sucker for the badass sci-fi art—any one of those cards would look just plain [i]awesome[/i] airbrushed onto a panel van.
PS. The Authority Cards (used to track "hit points" for game end) work just fine—they're not nearly as fiddly or inconvenient as others might have you believe. I love the fact that they allow for the entire game to fit in a standard hobby deck box with no need for extra bits like glass beads, dice, or even paper & pencil.
I dig the self-contained portability of the thing—in the end it's just a deck of cards. And that's perfect.
Includes select cards from:

item.name: Star Wars Miniatures
item.comment: Simple and fast system; a decent enough diversion with kids. The mounted board in the [i]Revenge of the Sith[/i] starter is a very nice touch. Collectible aspect blows flaming monkey chunks, however.

item.name: Star Wars: Epic Duels
item.comment: Transcends the usually mediocre Star Wars license. Very fun.

item.name: Star Wars: Jedi Unleashed
item.comment: An excellent teaching tool to show children that enemies slain on the battlefield become your slaves in the afterlife. (The winner is the one with the fattest ear-necklace at the end.)

item.name: Star Wars: X-Wing
item.comment:
[floatleft][size=18][b]AWWWW[/b][/size]
[imageid=266785] [size=18][b]YEEEEAH[/b][/size][/floatleft] I'm not really a [i]Star Wars[/i] fan—it's just that 89% of my childhood consisted of nothing but [i]Star Wars[/i], [i]The Empire Strikes Back[/i] and [i]Return of the Jedi[/i]. I was 10 when my Mom took me and a friend to see some weird space movie on opening day... If you were near that age and walked into it blind—[i]with a completely naked psyche[/i]—you get it. It was like being pulled hot off the anvil and thrust into a screaming slave's belly... Tempered in death and rebirth; shocking and permanently formative. A fulcrum point for generational shift.
As a kid I built X-wing and TIE fighter model kits until my fingers bled and I hallucinated glue-fume Jawas; I would have strangled the children & little people inside the rough brown cloaks with my inflatable lightsaber for a game like this. (Still would.) So to say that the perfectly detailed, tiny model ships resonate would be a massive understatement.
Again, I am not a fan; I find anything other than the original three movies—the "Expanded Universe", crappy novelizations, comics, Prequels, video games, etc., etc., ad nauseam—to be baby laxative.
But [i]X-Wing[/i] is the pure, uncut stuff, a high as dangerous as time travel and I'm 10 again.

item.comment: [center][imageid=1433772 original] [size=9][b]HORTON HEARS A CONCUSSION MISSILE[/b][/size][/center] I've always loved the Y-wing: armored and plodding, the thing is a pig that packs a wallop. Feels just right on the table, especially loaded with a double brace of proton torpedoes. There's nothing quite like locking a target, blasting 'em with the ion cannon to stop 'em dead and then cooking 'em off with a volley of torpedoes... unless it's doing it again!

item.name: Strange Synergy
item.comment:
A rock 'em sock 'em old-skool romp reminiscent of the [i]Champions[/i] RPG. Pretty fun, but it would benefit greatly from a little gloss, like, say, plastic minis with li'l plastic gadets/weapons and an actual cardboard game board with terrain tiles. Better production values could have pushed this to an 8... as is, it feels like you're playing a prototype rather than the finished game.
UPDATE: I get it. Plastic would have made this cost like eight million dollars. But still.

item.name: Stratego
item.comment: Fun with kids.

item.name: Strike Team Alpha
item.comment: Played this an awful lot in elementary school. We made up tons of new units and vehicles for this... Back then I probably would have given it a TEN!!! but it's far too old-skool to hold up. It's like playing a David Drake novel.

item.name: Striker
item.comment:
The 6 is for use as a table-top minis game... it gets a solid eleventy-billion when used to amp up the combat rules in the [rpg=491][i]Traveller[/i] RPG[/rpg].
PS. Box is long gone. Loved to tatters, then taped up and loved to trash. Now the books are starting to come apart... I imagine they'll end up as a hand-stained folio.

item.name: Survive: Escape from Atlantis!
item.comment:
Be the drunk guy in the lifeboat with the flare gun and the gas can... [i]sink it out of spite to kill the other two guys and deny everyone else the boat.[/i]
An ugly little game where the land sloughs off into an ocean boiling with hungry things. You try to drive your people to safety, everyone else drives the hungry things to their appointed dinners.
Who will make it off the island alive? The hairdresser or the Nobel Laureate?
My money's on NO ONE.
UPDATE: The art & design in the new 30th Anniversary Edition are flat-out brilliant. Also, having uniform plastic meeples is actually better than the misshapen, tippy wooden ones from the previous edition.
[size=24][b][u]\o/[/u][/b][/size]
It never hurts to make sure you're playing by the proper rules, right?
[b][thread=827200][/thread][/b]

item.name: Survive: Escape from Atlantis!
item.comment: (Gave this to Rusty.)

item.name: Sword and Skull
item.comment:
[i]Talismonopoly![/i]
An innocuous, light, roll-n-move family game. It carries just enough mutant gentic code from [i]Monopoly[/i] & [i]Talisman[/i] to be familiar and accessible to non-gamers and kids, but without any of the associated lethal alleles. Everyone gets to play 'til the end, and there are several balancing mechanisms to keep runaway leaders in check. Yes, it's powered by dice, but with two pawns per player and most rolls only letting you move one of them at a time there are choices to make. This is very much a family game, a "kick back and socialize" game, a "roll the dice and talk like a pirate whilst not caring too terrible much about what happens 'cuz we're all having too good a time just being together" game. Four-dimensional [i]Tigris & Euphrates[/i] it is not; it gets a 7 because we all had a good time, and really, what more can you ask from such things? Recommended for families.

item.name: Tales of the Arabian Nights
item.comment:
Facts about [i]Tales[/i]:
- God says NO.
- You can drink your way out of a rockslide.
- That which does not enrich you will grant you beatings.

item.name: Talisman (fourth edition)
item.comment: This is the filthy, kinder-begrubbed copy we take camping.

item.name: Talisman (fourth edition): The Blood Moon Expansion
item.comment:
[size=14][b]HORRIBLE BLACK VOID!!![/b][/size]
Yeah, now we can play the game as nature intended—as [i]True Men.[/i]
While I was initially worried at how it would fit in, the Time Card is actually pretty nifty (day/night sides that flip whenever an Event is drawn; creatures get -1 in combat during the day and +1 at night).
But the star of the show is the Werewolf, especially when combined with the Reaper—now you have [i]two[/i] forces of nature stalking the board for victims. It's especially good when using one or more corner boards... if everyone clusters up in the City, for example, you can expect the Werewolf & Reaper to converge there, creating a hideous oubliette where a simple shopping trip can end in horror.
[imageid=1319521 small]

item.name: Talisman (fourth edition): The City Expansion
item.comment:
One word:
[COLOR=#FF00FF][size=13][b]☆ GLITTER THE UNIC♡RN ☆[/b][/size][/COLOR]
[i]Fantastic![/i] Very different feel from the main game and other corner boards; tons of ways to make money and tons of stuff to spend it on. Pretty much solves the problem of being filthy rich and having nothing but crap to buy, akin to an old school episode of "Wheel of Fortune": "Yeah, I guess I'll take [i]another[/i] water bottle." It's the standard destination for loin-girding if you're not getting any love grinding for levels in the wider world.
Also, the Wharf space is terrific: Pay one gold to warp to any space in the outer or middle regions (!). This goes a long way to minimize the amount of dicking around required to get to the Warlock's Cave or Portal of Power.
[b]BUT BEST OF ALL ~[/b] There are several cards ([i]Corrupt Sheriff, Drunken Revelry, Taxation[/i]) that can yank clowns off the Crown of Command [i]and send them straight to jail.[/i]
[imageid=1577023 original]

item.name: Talisman (fourth edition): The Deep Realms Expansion
item.comment:
[i]The bridge or the hole?[/i]
These are the kinds of choices every aspirant of ultimate power must face.

item.name: Talisman (fourth edition): The Dragon Expansion
item.comment:
Kinda-sorta super-fiddly. It bogged the game down—but that might be because we had six players and [i]Talisman[/i] proper can drag, time-wise, with more than four. Looking forward to rerating after a play in the sweet spot.
Otherwise, yeah, [i]dragons.[/i] I was never really into them, don't think they're cool. I'd probably feel differently if I were a huge Anne McCaffrey nut, or had smoked a dragon-shaped bong in junior high, or owned a collection of those pewter-n-crystal statuettes... but, alas, I'm not, I haven't, and I don't.

item.name: Talisman (fourth edition): The Dungeon Expansion
item.comment:
The 10 is just a randomly-generated placeholder rating until I actually play it this weekend. With beer. And children.
UPDATE: This is probably the easiest 10 I've ever given a game or expansion. The extra characters and spells are almost worth the price alone, with the entire dungeon region and massive stack of dungeon cards acting merely as sweetener...
So much to love in here, like when the Summoning Circle gets clogged with an entire zoo of awfulness that no mortal can conquer, or the fact that it ups the burn rate on characters (we went through four character deaths—before the [i]purple-lightning-leaping-from-my-mouth-when-I-scream-your-name[/i] ending—in a three-player game).
Makes the game longer, almost twice as long for us, but I don't know how much of that was due to the fact that we all crammed in and oscillated in and out of the dungeon instead of ramping cleanly toward the Crown of Command.
UP-UPDATE: Played it as a stand-alone with the kids. [i]Talisman[/i] in 30 minutes!

item.name: Talisman (fourth edition): The Frostmarch Expansion
item.comment:
Pretty sure this will be a 10, but I'm waiting to play the Leprechaun before I commit.
UPDATE:
[imageid=1575978 original] So the Leprechaun pops into existence ♪ [i]Hidilly-Hodilly-Hee[/i] ♬ and skips across the rainbow to his pot o' gold; after filling his pockets he heads off to the raucous stink of the City where he is savaged by a werewolf, robbed of his funds, turned into a toad and evaporated by the Holy Host.
[b]DEFINITELY A 10[/b]

item.name: Talisman (fourth edition): The Reaper Expansion
item.comment:
Four new characters, a [i]ton[/i] of new adventure cards, a huge number of new spells... not to mention the brand new Warlock Quest deck and, of course, the Grim Reaper Hisself!
This is a no-brainer for every [i]Talisman[/i] fan—fighting over the Grim Reaper (shifting him back and forth in an attempt to get him to land on someone) adds even more balls-out screwage to an already nails-in-a-baseball-bat game.
An absolute must-have for every Talismanite!
[imageid=1575978 original] [size=7][i]"Well, well, well. Look at you all dressed up in spats and ignorance."[/i][/size]
[microbadge=3148]
[b][thread=984997][/thread][/b]

item.name: Talisman (fourth edition): The Sacred Pool Expansion
item.comment:
The stables and Quest Reward cards are cool. Also, one of the alternative endings is a true co-op game. Nice!
As for characters, the Dread Knight is pretty much the only one my #1 son will play—he comes with a graveyard-regenerating warhorse and gains a spell for every enemy he defeats. [i]Bad. Ass.[/i] I'm partial to the Magus purely because he gets lugged around by a bevy of oiled slaves in his fabulous sedan chair.
"Tread with care, fools! Dump me in the mud again and there will be hell to pay! This time I swear it!"

item.name: Talisman (Revised 4th Edition)
item.comment:
[center][size=6][COLOR=#878787]LIFETIME GAME [microbadge=28495]:star:[microbadge=28496] "PLAY FOREVER"[/COLOR][/size][/center]
[i][b]L[/b]ife is hard and the Gods are cruel; we toil for their amusement and even our best, most heroic efforts are but castles in the sand before the rushing tide. The Crown of Command dangles as a carrot on the end of a very beaty stick, existing only to see who will neck-stab whom for the illusion of control. We go now, doughty adventurers, hopping across this stage as toads to make the Gods—and perhaps ourselves—laugh. In the end, some lucky bastard will "win"—though he or she will most likely be consumed in capricious flames whence the curtain falls on this pointless shadow play.[/i]
[microbadge=2915]
This is NOT a nostalgia rating—I never got a chance to play this as a kid, teen, or college student. Though I probably would have spent an awful lot of time doing so if I'd had the chance...
This is a GREAT nerd party/time-waster/beer, pretzels & potty-mouth game. It has clumsy, outdated mechanics, "unfair" amounts of luck, and the ancient, tired and beaten-to-death [i]Lord of the Rings/D&D[/i] rip-off theme.
And I love it.
This is, in many ways, the Ultimate "Gone-Stupid" Game. You can pull your brain out of gear and just coast along; it's one for those times when you would like to play a game, but life has hammered you down to the point where you just want to go "guh."
So roll a die, pull a card, read the result aaand...
ENJOY!
UPDATE: Many people decry the random, binary movement system (roll a die and choose either right or left) but this simplicity is part of what makes [i]Talisman[/i] great—it's the only game of its ilk in which downtime is not an issue. While [i]Runebound[/i] begins to drag at three players (and becomes intolerable with any more), [i]Talisman[/i] can support the full compliment of players and the turns literally whiz around the table. Roll, pick, do the thing, pass the dice. It's almost a party game, it's so fast.
PS. The new Fantasy Flight upgrade is fab! Looking very forward to a whole mess of expansions...
UP-UPDATE: With renewed family interest this has been hitting the table as a weekly event! The good news, other than getting to play one of my favorite "weird storytelling" games, is that all the kids are hot to paint the scads of minis. Several nights now I've gone to sleep only to wake to finished minis in the morning. If you can engineer this effect for yourself I highly recommend it.
The only minor downer is that what makes this game fantastic is also the one thing that can kill it. The utterly random element, so brilliant as a jumping-off point for spit-takes—like when the Leprechaun gets the Princess as a follower and ends up being lugged around in a front-facing baby carrier with a boob on each shoulder—can make the game excruciatingly slow when the cards don't come out in a useful manner. After a couple of games of watching others level up ferociously while I got in multiple fights with a Royal Decree, three Horse Stables, several Bags of Gold, and a New Age strip-mall (the Mage, Healer and some dude hawking tie-dyed bedsheets decided to clog up the Hidden Valley), I've come to realize that more than anything else this game requires [i]stamina.[/i] [floatright][imageid=1374144 small] [size=7]Fig. 1 — [i]!!![/i][/size][/floatright] With all the Adventure Cards from all the expansions, I'm thinking I might need to go through and trim the deck down to tighten up the game... though I'm conflicted, as [i]Talisman[/i] really is about embracing pure chaos and not every story should follow standard Fantasy tropes. Sometimes it's okay if the Ogre Chieftain's saga is one of administration, finances and horse-trading.
